newsitem.title: FINLAND: Markka ERM peg at present levels seen drawing near.
newsitem.headline: Markka ERM peg at present levels seen drawing near.

text.p: Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen on Monday indicated a decision to link the Finnish markka to the European Exchange Mechanism (ERM) was drawing near and the central parity exchange rate would be on the firm side, analysts said.
Lipponen was quoted as telling a regional newspaper that the time was ripe to decide in the near future about a link to the European currency grid within which some European currencies float.
He also suggested there would be no official attempt to influence the central parity rate at which the markka was fixed in the ERM.

"The level of the markka cannot be manipulated. It would be noticed immediately and it would weaken the confidence in Finland," the paper quoted Lipponen as saying. "He indicated that a fix could happen at stronger levels than earlier thought," said Interbank economist Sampsa Laine.
"It could be below 3.05 (markka per German mark). What he said could even be interpreted as making possible a peg below 3.03."
The reaction on the foreign exchange market on Monday morning supported this conclusion, analysts said.

The markka strengthened as Finnish exporters began to convert foreign currency earnings into markka having taken the prime minister at his word and stopped hoping for a weaker ERM peg, the analysts said.
At 0930 GMT, the markka was at 3.018 against the German mark having traded well above 3.02 before news broke of Lipponen's comments. It closed at 3.0225 last Friday.
But Pertti Thornberg, analyst at Enskilda, said nothing specific about the markka's central parity exchange rates in ERM should be read into the prime minister's comments.
"The level could be 3.02 (markka per mark), or it could be 3.06 or 3.07," he said.
Of eight analysts polled by Reuters, six now expect the link to take place soon. But they noted that Lipponen had not given any clear clue about the timing.
Handelsbanken Finland chief economist Carlo Erakallio said he still expected the linking of the markka to the ERM to take place later this autumn with November the likeliest month.
But the government may opt to make a quick formal decision in favour of a peg and so reaffirm its commitment to European economic and monetary union (EMU), he said.
Some of the analysts said the right time to link the markka could be in connection with the coming weekend's meeting of EU finance and economy ministers in Dublin.
